comments:
Accounting 101 focuses on teaching the student to learn to read, understand, and analyze financial statements. The course adopts a decision-maker perspective of accounting by emphasizing the relation between accounting data and the underlying economic events that generated them. The course focuses initially on how to record economic events in the accounting records (i.e., bookkeeping and accrual accounting) and how to prepare and interpret the primary financial statements that summarize a firm's economic transactions (i.e., the balance sheet, the income statement, and the statement of cash flows). The course then examines in depth the major asset, long-term liability, and shareholders' equity accounts. 

Many students thought that the course was “boring,” but an equal number remarked that the real-life examples used in the class kept them engaged in the material. Students agreed that the material was very “relevant” to their future careers.

Students found Professor Balakrishnan to be a great lecturer who did a good job conveying the material through “humorous examples.” Students enjoyed Professor Balakrishnan’s “enthusiasm” and also remarked that he was readily available to meet outside of class.

Many students criticized the multiple-choice exam format and the “harsh curve,” but they also agreed that the exams closely paralleled what was taught in class. The course is intended for students with no previous exposure to financial accounting. It is part of the core requirements in Wharton.

Accounting 101 is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts will be studied in detail, including: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long-term liabilities. ACCT 101 emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements- the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement- as well at their interpretation. 

Some students found the material to be “very dry.”  A few students commented, however, that the course covers a lot of information that “is integral to anyone going into business.”  Several highlighted that the lecture slides were important to the structure of the course and to learning the material.  

Almost all students liked Professor Taylor.  A number of students mentioned his “dry wit” and appreciated his ability to make “the very dry subject of accounting interesting.”  Generally, students felt that Professor Taylor was “effective at communicating the subject matter.”  However, many students also commented on the fast pace of the lectures.  A few students appreciated the fast pace because it meant getting out of class early.  However, several wished that Professor Taylor “would explain the material more thoroughly rather than just read through the slides.”  A couple of students noted that they could “never keep up” during lecture and needed to go back through the lecture slides multiple times before understanding them.  Most students felt that Professor Taylor was “accessible” and “good at answering questions.”  However, a few students noted that his cold calling could be “intimidating.”

ACCT 101 is part of the Wharton core and has no prerequisites.  Grading is based on homework assignments, midterms, and the final.  A couple of students said they disliked the multiple-choice format of the tests, as “there was no partial credit” and a few mistakes “could dramatically lower your grade.”  A number of other students, however, mentioned that the material on the exams was “in line with the content that was taught” and that studying the lectures slides, homework, and especially the practice tests was a good way to prepare.  A few noted that “test questions were very similar to the practice test questions.”

This course is a recitation for ACCT101, Principles of Accounting. This course is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts are studied in detail, including: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long-term liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as their interpretation.

Students for the most part did not feel that they gained much from this recitation. One student noted that students hardly ever attended the recitation. Another student explained that the recitations were flawed by design because they included very few problems from which to work and teach. 

Although one student insisted that Mr. Tsui was a “good teacher,” the overwhelming majority of the students’ comments were negative. One student mentioned that Mr. Tsui frequently arrived late to class. Another student described Mr. Tsui as being uninterested in helping students. A different student mentioned that Mr. Tsui, in an attempt to teach, would do the problems on the board, but he would not explain them well enough.

In regards to target audience, all of the students in this course enrolled because it is a mandatory recitation for ACCT101. As far as workload is concerned, this course is heavy on problem solving and mathematics.

This course is a recitation for Principles of Accounting I, an introduction to the
basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Concepts studied
include: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long-term
liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting
statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as
their interpretation.
Overall, students did not find this recitation very useful. Though the time was
designated for review problems, students found the TA’s were often unprepared to solve
the problems, and spent a long time figuring them out, or skipping over problems entirely
because they found them irrelevant.
Students had numerous complaints about Isacoff’s availability as a teaching
assistant. Although he was “great at explaining concepts in a way that made sense,”
students unanimously reported that Isacoff was constantly canceling class, and sending
them to other TA’s recitations. They also complained that he did not respond to emails or
attend his office hours. Students reported seeing Isaacson an average of two times over
the course of the semester.
The majority of students in ACCT 101 were in the Wharton School, taking this
class to fill the core requirement. Attendance to recitation was not factored into the
grades for ACCT 101.
*Based on 5 written reviews.
